questions.prompt: A Turing machine differs from a PDA by:
options: Having a read/write tape head that moves both directions
questions.explanation: A TM has an infinite read/write tape with a head that can move left or right, unlike a PDA's one-way input and LIFO stack.

questions.prompt: A TM transition δ(q, a) = (r, b, L) means:
options: Read b, write a, move right
In state q reading a, write b, move left, go to state r
Move to state a from state q
questions.explanation: The transition reads a in state q, writes b, moves head left (L), and transitions to state r.

questions.prompt: A TM accepts an input if:
options: It ever visits an accept state
It halts in an accept state
questions.explanation: A TM accepts by entering the accept state q_accept. It rejects by entering q_reject or may loop forever.

options: Some TM accepts exactly its strings (may not halt on non-members)
questions.explanation: Turing-recognizable (r.e.) languages have TMs that accept all members. The TM may loop forever on non-members.

options: Some TM accepts members and rejects non-members (always halts)
questions.explanation: Decidable (recursive) languages have TMs that halt on all inputs, accepting members and rejecting non-members.

options: Are more powerful than single-tape TMs
Are equivalent in power to single-tape TMs
questions.explanation: Multi-tape TMs can be simulated by single-tape TMs (with polynomial slowdown). They recognize the same languages.

options: Are strictly more powerful than deterministic TMs
Recognize the same languages as deterministic TMs
questions.explanation: NTMs and DTMs are equivalent in computational power - they recognize the same languages (though DTM simulation may be slower).

options: Can simulate any other TM given its encoding
Is faster than all other TMs
questions.explanation: The UTM takes ⟨M, w⟩ as input and simulates M on w. It can run any TM, making it a "programmable computer."

questions.prompt: To design a TM for {ww | w ∈ {a,b}*}:
options: Use a single-tape TM with one pass
It is impossible - language not recognizable
questions.explanation: A TM can mark/cross off symbols while zigzagging to compare the two halves. This requires read/write and bidirectional movement.

questions.prompt: Encoding a TM as a string allows:
options: TMs to take other TMs as input
questions.explanation: String encoding enables TMs to operate on descriptions of other TMs, essential for the UTM and undecidability proofs.

options: Turing machines are the fastest model of computation
Any effectively computable function can be computed by a TM
questions.explanation: The thesis asserts TMs capture the intuitive notion of "algorithm" - anything we'd consider computable can be TM-computed.
The thesis cannot be mathematically proven because "effectively computable" is an informal notion. It is strongly supported by evidence.

questions.prompt: Which model is NOT equivalent to Turing machines?
questions.explanation: Finite automata are strictly weaker than TMs - they can only recognize regular languages, not all decidable languages.

questions.prompt: Evidence for the Church-Turing thesis includes:
options: All proposed computation models are equivalent to TMs
questions.explanation: Every reasonable computation model proposed (lambda calculus, recursive functions, etc.) has been proven equivalent to TMs.

questions.prompt: Modern computers compared to Turing machines:
options: Have the same computational power (with unlimited memory)
Are strictly less powerful even with unlimited memory
questions.explanation: With unlimited memory, a computer has exactly TM power. Real computers are limited by finite memory but theoretically equivalent.
